awd_titl_txt: Chemical Coupling of Halogens and Oxygenated VOC (Volatile Organic Compounds): Observations, Experiments and Modeling
awd_abstract_narration:
This project includes field observations, laboratory experiments, and modeling tasks designed to investigate the chemistry associated with halogens, such as bromine and iodine, in the atmosphere.  Measurements will be made at two mountain top observatories (Maido in the Southern Hemisphere tropical Indian Ocean and Mauna Loa in the Northern Hemisphere tropical Pacific Ocean) to assess the seasonal variability of halogen concentrations. This research will provide critical new information for assessing the extent to which tropospheric halogens modify the lifetime of tropospheric ozone, a potent greenhouse gas, and serve as a precursor for the formation of hydroxyl radicals, that influence the lifetime of atmospheric methane. Thus the results will be directly relevant for modeling future climate change.

Laboratory experiments will be conducted to investigate the reaction mechanism of bromine radicals with unsaturated oxygenated volatile organic compounds (OVOC) that can form from aliphatic acids in marine air and the potential for product yields of glyoxal and aliphatic aldehydes.  Modeling efforts will compare field measurements with the results of global models to assess the impacts of the BrOx sink from OVOC for halogen impacts on tropospheric ozone, methane, and atmospheric mercury.

por.por_cntn:
The project developed infrastructure at two remote observatories located on islands in the remote tropical lower free troposphere (FT) to conduct long-term observations of bromine oxide (BrO) radicals, iodine oxide (IO) radicals, nitrogen dioxide (NO2) radicals and oxygenated hydrocarbon (OVOC) abundances, assess seasonal variations in remote background air of both the Northern and Southern hemispheres. These field observations were combined with laboratory experiments to help improve atmospheric models. The field measurements fill an observational gap in available data under which to evaluate atmospheric models. Specifically, our measurements help characterize the impact of the Hunga Tonga submarine volcanic eruption on ozone loss in the stratosphere, help understand ozone chemistry in aged wildfire plumes originating from South Africa, mercury oxidation in remote air, particle formation, and the removal of greenhouse gases in some of the most remote and understudied atmospheric environments of our planet's atmosphere. 

The results are relevant to atmospheric dynamics, toxicology, public health (mercury), and climate science. Halogens and organic carbon modify oxidative capacity, the lifetimes of two important greenhouse gases (ozone and methane), and iodine forms aerosols that affect the energy balance of Earth's atmosphere. Halogen-induced ozone loss is relevant to ozone abundances in the upper troposphere and lower stratosphere, and affects climate sensitivities, because of a large ozone circulation feedback and its implications for global warming assessments. Changes in ozone in the upper troposphere and lower stratosphere have been analyzed using aircraft datasets.

The geochemical cycle of iodine involves partitioning of iodine between the gas and particle phases, and also has implications for aerosol chemistry, new particle formation, and growth. Iodine in the lower stratosphere was quantified, and has implications for the recovery of the ozone layer. The discovery of the gas-phase formation mechanism of iodic acid (HIO3) in well controlled laboratory experiments is found to explain field observations of IO radicals and iodic acid (HIO3) at Maido Observatory. Our results link iodine sources with new particle formation at the molecular level, and suggest iodine plays a catalytic role in particle formation (see image). Field measurements at the Maido Observatory (see image) provided a real world test for the laboratory findings.

Furthermore, measurements of bromine radical abundances directly inform the oxidation rates and the lifetime of mercury in the atmosphere. The oxidation of elemental mercury by bromine is an important source of water-soluble oxidized mercury in the atmosphere. Mercury is a neurotoxin that bioaccumulates in fish, and is therefore a public health concern. 

Society benefits from improved knowledge about the sinks of ozone and methane and a better understanding of our changing environment. With more than 40% of the world's oceans now heavily affected by human activities, the project addresses the urgent need to better characterize pristine pre-industrial-like atmospheric environments that still exist over remote tropical oceans under pristine conditions, and sporadically experience pollution influences from natural hazards (here: wildfires, volcanoes).

Graduate students and a postdoctoral researcher have been trained through a combination of field studies, teamwork, hands on laboratory experiments, data analysis, and instrument development and automatisation; and have developed transferrable skills by working as part of an interdisciplinary team of scientists, engineers, staff with diverse expertise and cultural backgrounds that prepare them well as globally engaged and active members of society for jobs in academia, government, or industry.
